headline: The Lead with Jake Tapper
subHeadline: Acting Secret Service Dir.: Information About Shooter "Siloed" And "Stuck" In Local Law Enforcement Channels; Sen. Gary Peters, (D- MI), Is Interviewed About Secret Service, Kamala Harris, Immigration, VP Running Mate; Trump's First Major Ad Hits Harris On Immigration; Axios: Sen. Gary Peters Emerges As Harris VP Dark Horse; IDF: Strike In Beirut "Eliminated" Hezbollah Commander; Some Billionaire Donors Want Harris To Replace Head Lina Khan; Trump On Vance's "Childless Cat Lady" Comments; CNN KFile: JD Vance Has History Of Disparaging People Without Kids; Source: Harris & Future VP Pick To Visit Battleground States Next Week; Behind The Scenes: Roberts' Power Play In The U.S. Supreme Court's Biggest Case Of The Year. Aired 5-6p ET

utterances.speaker: JAKE TAPPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Welcome to The Lead. I'm Jake Tapper. This hour as vice president Kamala Harris campaigns in a key battleground state, I'll be joined by one of her possible vice presidential contenders. Plus a tech billionaire going all in for the Harris campaign who is suggesting she should make a major change if she wins in November. Plus new exclusive reporting on what happened behind the scenes as the U.S. Supreme Court debated whether Donald Trump could be immune from criminal prosecution.And leading this hour, a failure on multiple levels, that's how the acting head of the U.S. Secret Service detail what happened with security protocol calls and the hours and minutes before the assassination attempt on former President Donald Trump. Ronald Rowe testified during a contentious hearing before Senate lawmakers earlier today. He admitted that even though local officers warned about a man with a gun on a nearby roof, that information never made it to the U.S. Secret Service or to Trump's personal security detail. Rowe also promised that people will be held accountable once the multiple investigations into what happened had been completed. CNN's Whitney Wild starts off our coverage of this hour with more details on how the U.S. Secret Service is working to try to prevent anything like this from ever happening again. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) RONALD ROWE JR., ACTING SECRET SERVICE DIRECTOR: You're asking me, senator, to completely make a rush to judgment about somebody failing. I acknowledge this was a failure of the Secret Service -- SEN. JOSH HAWLEY (R-MO): Is it not prima facie that somebody has failed. The former president was shot. WHITNEY WILD, CNN LAW ENFORCEMENT CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): A fierce exchange between Senator Josh Hawley and Acting Secret Service Director Ron Rowe as Hawley pushed for more accountability after the attempted assassination of Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: ROWE
utterances.sentences: I have lost sleep over that for the last 17 days just like --

utterances.speaker: HAWLEY
utterances.sentences: Then fire somebody to hold Secret Service accountable.

utterances.speaker: ROWE
utterances.sentences: I will tell you, people will be held accountable, and I will do so with integrity and not rush to judgment and put people unfairly persecuted.

utterances.speaker: HAWLEY
utterances.sentences: I can't believe that you are -- unfairly persecuted? We got people who are dead.

utterances.speaker: ROWE
utterances.sentences: Unfairly, sir. We have --WILD (voice-over): For more than three hours, senators pressed Rowe on how a gunman could possibly shoot at former President Donald Trump from the roof just 150 yards from Trump's podium. Rowe insisted that building was supposed to be covered by local law enforcement.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Isn't that something that secret service should have covered?

utterances.speaker: ROWE
utterances.sentences: We assumed that the state and locals had it.WILD (voice-over): For the first time the Secret Service provided photos that showed the Vantage Point local snipers positioned inside the building would have seen and that could have given them a clearer look at Thomas Crooks on the roof where he fired shots.

utterances.speaker: ROWE
utterances.sentences: I cannot understand why there was not better coverage or at least somebody looking at that roofline when that's where they were posted.WILD (voice-over): Rowe detailed major breakdowns in communication saying local law enforcement knew Crooks had a weapon seconds before he shot. But that information never made it to the Secret Service.

utterances.speaker: ROWE
utterances.sentences: It appears that that information was stuck or siloed in that state and local channel. Nothing about man on the roof. Nothing about man with a gun. None of that information ever made it over our net.WILD (voice-over): Rowe also described failures of technology. According to the FBI, Crooks flew a drone above the rally around 3:50 p.m. about two hours before the shooting. The Secret Service had technology to defeat drones, but the system wasn't working until after 5:00 p.m.

utterances.speaker: ROWE
utterances.sentences: I have no explanation for it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: ROWE
utterances.sentences: It is something that I feel as though we could have perhaps found him, we could have maybe stopped him.(END VIDEO CLIP) WILD (on camera): Jake, the FBI was also in that hearing and they have not yet been able to determine a motive but they did offer a little bit more insight into the shooters mindset. The FBI saying that the shooter had two social media accounts on Gab, one of those accounts associated with the shooter seem to reflect anti-semitic and anti- immigration themes. Well, another one of those accounts appears to have offered different points of view, Jake. Again, still no motive there.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PETERS
utterances.sentences: And about 30 seconds went by before the shot and those counter snipers took the shot, 30 seconds, that's a lot of time. If you had -- if you were on the call immediately, it's a guy with a gun on the roof, immediately the counter snipers would have immediately zoned in and they have prevented the catastrophic shooting that we saw.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Do you agree with Senator Hawley that more people -- I mean, obviously, the former director of the CIA -- I mean, of the Secret Service, Kimberly Cheatle, obviously she's resigned. But do you agree with Josh, Senator Hawley, that more people should have lost their jobs by now? Because he seemed upset that 17 days later, in his view, there wasn't enough accountability?

utterances.speaker: PETERS
utterances.sentences: Well, there needs to be accountability. There's no argument with that. There needs to be accountability. This was without question catastrophic. In fact, you heard the director in his opening testimony, he said, you know, he actually went up on the roof laid down where the shooter was, and he said, you know, I'm ashamed, and this, I have no way I can possibly defend this, this should have never occurred.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So it raises all the questions we're going to raise, like what kind of security plan was in place? So, you know, he's pointing fingers at local law enforcement. But shouldn't their security plans see this vulnerability of the high ground relatively close, certainly within shooting distance of the stage? Why was that not secured by Secret Service agents and not a local police force?

utterances.speaker: PETERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, when you look at the map, it seems pretty obvious that somebody should be watching that roof. It's close and it's right there.

utterances.speaker: PETERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: I want to turn to another big issue for the Homeland Security Committee Immigration. Former president Trump is -- has a first major ad out, T.V. ad, hitting Vice President Kamala Harris hard on immigration. You're the chair of the Homeland Security Committee. I'm wondering, what you think about the fact that your nominee is now the person who was whether or not she was actually officially a boarder czar, she certainly had a leadership responsibility in -- on the issue of immigration, she was in charge of going to the countries in Central America and stemming the tide there at this Edit Source, that that person is now your party's nominee. To some observers, it might look like you're doubling down on a weakness for your party.

utterances.speaker: PETERS
utterances.sentences: Well, she was not the czar.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PETERS
utterances.sentences: She was tasked with dealing with the triangle there with folks that are coming from Central America that are coming north, and how do you stem some of that migration? What sort of resources need to be put in place to have people stay? Most people --

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: She still had a leadership role on that issue, though, is my point.

utterances.speaker: PETERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, there's no question about that. But she did not have all encompassing oversight of that by any means. And if you look at where we are right now, actually, the number of folks coming across the border are at a low for the Biden presidency and actually are a little lower than when Donald Trump was president. So there have been actions taken.But I think you have -- we also have to remember that for both presidents what we need to have and what we've been working on in Homeland Security is you need to have changes in law to deal with the asylum system. Those have to be legal, otherwise are challenged in court. We know what happened last time, it was overthrown. And we were very close. We had a bipartisan agreement, which was significant that was coming before the Senate and then Donald Trump told his folks don't vote for that, I don't want to solve the problem, I want to use this as a political issue. The American people have to know we were close to coming together in a bipartisan way to have probably passed the most significant legislation dealing with border issues and decades and Donald Trump's stop that from happening.

utterances.speaker: PETERS
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm -- I respect the process. And as you know how these process goes, I don't want to talk about any of that. The process is something the Vice President is going through. She's looking at a number of folks. She's got a long list of people she can be talking to. And whoever is the nominee, I will fully support.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Do you think it's important that you pick somebody from the swath of Midwestern states that goes from Minnesota to Pennsylvania. Whether or not it's you, somebody in that part of the country that Democrats cannot keep the White House if you don't win Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Michigan?

utterances.speaker: PETERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think that's safe to say. I wouldn't say Michigan, I didn't say it's impossible to be a president if you don't win Michigan, but clearly Pennsylvania, Wisconsin are in that group as well. So it's critically important. But with also unions, as you mentioned, Joe Biden was, without question, the most pro union president, he was on picket lines with the UAW. I was out there with him. Members appreciated the fact that he was authentic.And that's a big issue in Michigan, particularly now with labor unions having success. The success the UAW had in their last contract negotiation, not only increase the wages of UAW members, but increase the wages of folks throughout Michigan because when unions are successful, everybody is successful. And pro union is a critically important topic. And I know Kamala Harris is pro union. I know she's been on picket lines since that fact, she walked up a picket line for the SEIU in Michigan. She cares about that, but we need to also make sure we're focusing on the union movement and how that strengthens the American middle class.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: We have breaking news for you now on our world lead, the Israeli military, the IDF, just announced a strike in Beirut, Lebanon a few hours ago, quote, "eliminated," end quote, the Hezbollah commander that Israel blames for Saturday's rocket attack that killed 12 children in the Golan Heights. The man was also wanted by the United States, we should note, in connection with the 1983 Marine barracks bombing in Beirut, which killed hundreds. Moments ago in Atlanta, Vice President Kamala Harris defended Israel's actions but also called for a negotiated peace deal to end the fighting.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: KAMALA HARRIS, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: I want to address what's happened over the last few hours in terms of the Middle East. And be very clear Israel has the right to defend itself. And I unequivocally support Israel's right to remain secure and to defend the security of Israel. What we know in particular is, yes, it has the right to defend itself against the terrorist organization which is exactly what Hezbollah is. But all of that being said we still must work on a diplomatic solution to end these attacks and we will continue to do that work.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: With us now, retired U.S. Air Force colonel and CNN military analyst Cedric Leighton.A U.S. official, Colonel Leighton, tells CNN that Israeli forces targeted Fu'ad Shukr, senior adviser to Hezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah, Shukr is also wanted by the U.S. for his role in the 1983 Marine barracks bombing in Beirut, the IDF just announced he was eliminated, and the strike What more do you know about him? COL. CEDRIC LEIGHTON (RET.), CNN MILITARY ANALYST: So basically, Jake, he was the number three guy in Hezbollah according to what the Israeli intelligence services have said, and also what U.S. intelligence is reporting. So the basic de hierarchy here for him was that he was basically the strategic adviser to Nasrallah. And that put him in a very key position within Hezbollah. So he was a key target, and a key person to eliminate.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Obviously, people are worried about a wider conflict breaking out or Israel's fighting multiple fronts, although it certainly already is, in some ways. Do you think that the strike amounts to a limited action to send a message to Hezbollah, but not big enough, so that all out regional war would break out?

utterances.speaker: LEIGHTON
utterances.sentences: But I think the Israelis have gambled that that's the case. In other words, they think this is a limited strike going after one particular individual. But this is a very high level individual. And it could very well result in an escalation. The Israelis believe that this will be a limited -- have a limited impact on what Hezbollah does next.But I think we have to really be careful, but with how this escalatory ladder minds unravel at this particular point. So that I think remains to be seen whether or not the Israeli gamble will pay off.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Hezbollah has been firing rockets into Israel ever since right after the Hamas attacks. On October 7, Israel responding in kind. Is it possible that Saturday's rocket strike in the Golan Heights that killed these 12 kids was an errant rocket and not intended for that part of the Golan Heights?

utterances.speaker: LEIGHTON
utterances.sentences: It's very possible that that is the case, Jake. One of the reports that we've seen from the Israelis is that they believe that it is actually -- was actually an errant missile. The range of the missiles was fairly short range, it's about a 10 kilometers six mile range. It is easy to misfire missiles like this. And if they don't have the right fuel mix, it's possible that they could have gone off by accident were targeted the wrong area. The fact that they targeted a Druze community also indicates that this may have been a mistake because Hezbollah normally does not want to alienate the Druze population.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Reid Hoffman joins us now. Reid, thanks for joining us. So you and other big money donors are giving money to Vice President Harris suggesting also that she replace the head of the FTC, which impacts policy in the economy. What do you say to somebody who watches this and says, this isn't how American politics should work, rich people getting to buy levels of influence?

utterances.speaker: HOFFMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, I totally agree with not buying levels of influence, I separate my role as a donor and expert. So if you ask me as a donor, I say I'm giving money to Kamala Harris because I think she's the best future president for the U.S. for business, for a bunch of other things. If you asked me as an expert about what, you know, kind of Lina Khan is doing and where I think she is helping or hurting America relative to your anti merger policies, which are, you know, mostly to bring litigation versus, you know, really solidly grounded and kind of what's going on, what helps American business thrive here and overseas, then I give an expert opinion. But I think donor an expert should be kept separate. And I've never tied the two ever, in any conversation anywhere I've ever had.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right? But I mean, that world doesn't really exist where people say, OK, now I'm talking to Reid Hoffman, the donor, and Reid Hoffman, the guy with political ideas, I'm going to put into the other room. I mean, politicians are human. And if they know that you and Barry Diller and other big donors are giving a lot of cash and want to get rid of Lina Khan from the FTC, they might listen to that more than they would listen to it from somebody in a restaurant.

utterances.speaker: HOFFMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, this is one of the things where I don't ever show up at the White House saying, I think you should do this. I mean, one of the things that President Biden has said to me every time he's met me, is I never asked for anything, because all I'm trying to do is help our leaders be the best governors.Now, if I'm asked as an expert, and you know, for example, shows like this, CNN, you know, say, well, what do you think, is the right expert point of view? I would say, well, here's what I think as an expert, and maybe people will listen to me more, and maybe you'll have me on television, because I'm a donor. But I definitely myself distinguish between my role as a donor and my role as an expert. And I don't ever -- when I'm doing fundraisers or anything else, I never say, you know, I'm only going to do a fundraiser for you, if, or, you know, since we're doing this fundraiser right now, where I'm raising money for you, I want you to hear my opinion on X. I respond to questions and expertise on them.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So you sit on the board of Microsoft, and that, of course, is a company that has multiple FTC run ins, right now, there's an open FTC investigation into whether Microsoft structured one of its deals with your startup Inflexion AI in order to avoid a government review, that's according to reporting from both CNN and the Wall Street Journal. You're donating millions to Harris, while publicly stating you hope she replaces the FTC head who is leading that very investigation? Doesn't that create an inherent conflict?

utterances.speaker: HOFFMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, let me talk about as a venture capitalist, because I've never talked about these things as a board member, I would say that one of the things that is the theory behind what the FTC does is to say let's create more competition for our tech companies. But if what you're doing is making acquisitions much more difficult out of the tech industry because these are small nation companies like Inflexion has no revenue, you know, et cetera, et cetera has a little bit now before its commercial deal with Microsoft, then you're creating less incentive for investment, less incentive or creating potential competition because you're blocking M&A exits. And so, you know, when I speak to these things, I speak more as a venture capitalist, I never speak as a Microsoft board member.Now, even in the Inflexion case, it is complicating in a set of things across venture investments, that if anytime that you're prospectively going to be purchased by one of the large tech companies, it may take, you know, years and review, may have, you know, kind of arbitrarily being challenged or investigated, then you're going to -- it's going to quell investment. And that's bad for creating new competitors.

utterances.speaker: HOFFMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, But to be clear, for example, I've never had a conversation with Kamala Harris about this, right? This is all like, I made a comment because it was like, What do you think about Kamala Harris for business? And I said, look, I think she's great rule of law. It's one of the backgrounds I think, was one of the reasons she's better than Trump. But I do have some things where I, you know, just as an expert, I would say that there would be things that could be improved in a Harris administration and the stuff and that was an example. But like, I don't talk to her about that.Now, of course, we can have these conversations. And you can say, hey, you know, she's not making this distinguished. So let's have this long conversation on CNN about it. And so she might watch our segment. And that's the way she would hear about as you talking to me. TAPPER: Right. You and other donors went after Lina Khan pretty quickly after Biden announced he was dropping out of the 2024 race. Do you have any concerns this might hurt the Democratic party unity that we've seen demonstrations of in the last few days?

utterances.speaker: HOFFMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, I hope not. It is interesting to me that of all of Biden's appointees, JD Vance is most enthusiastic about Lina Khan. And maybe that has some, you know, swing voter implication implications. And maybe also, you know, some -- I've also gotten a bunch of feedback from, you know, a bunch of people I deeply respect within the Democratic ecosystem saying, well, you know, we're much more positive than you and I'm like, look, I love what she's done on anti competes with employees. I dislike what she's been doing on and I think it's bad for investment on kind of anti-trust and investment.So, you know, so like, it's again, you know, what I worry that it has a potential negative, sure, but I try to be a truth teller when I'm asked questions about what I actually think about what's good for America.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Reid Hoffman, thanks so much for your time and for coming on the show and answering your questions. Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: HOFFMAN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And we're back with the 2024 lead. Democratic mega donor Reid Hoffman just moments ago telling me he has never put any conditions on his millions of dollars of support for Kamala Harris despite saying this week that he would hope President Harris would replace progressive darling FTC chair Lina Khan. The panel is here to discuss.Alencia, you heard Reid Hoffman's explanation that donor Reid Hoffman is not the same person as not a fan of Lina Kahn, Reid Hoffman, which is not the same person as Microsoft board member, Reid Hoffman, Microsoft being under investigation by the FTC. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: ALENCIA JOHNSON, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST
utterances.sentences: Look, I think that you're seeing the reason that there's so many factions of the Democratic Party who get frustrated with how money tends to drive our politics. I worked for Elizabeth Warren's presidential campaign and we were against these major donors making the big decisions. You know, I think Vice President Harris is going to have to be very clear on where she stands, if she stands with workers and unions and workers rights and all this that she actually spent last week talking about -- talking to a lot of different unions. And so, it's interesting that he says that he is not telling her to make a decision, but going on national television after such a big donation is saying what you want to happen. And it's really frustrating because, you know, you all report it, we raised over $20 million in the first week. Majority of those donors were small donors, were first time donors who they want that -- they want to make sure that their president is going to look out for them and not the wealthy.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: It was also interesting how he cited JD Vance, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, Donald Trump's running mate as saying -- he said that Lina Khan's favorite person in the Biden Harris cabinet --

utterances.speaker: SHERMICHAEL SINGLETON, CNN CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: I noticed that.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: -- as if that that's a negative, when actually it could be argued that you know, JD Vance childless cat ladies aside, like, it's actually part of this kind of like more populist view of corporate America that some minority but some in the Republican Party express.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: Although JD Vance also has a lot of very wealthy rich friends, Jake. And I think --

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: -- it's interesting, proclivities of some of these wealthier donors and attempting to dictate what policy positions of a candidate should be. You definitely need the money running for electoral office in general is expensive, this is going to be an expensive race. There are a lot of voters, particularly if you're Trump, they're looking at low propensity voters, those voters to target engage, even figuring out where they are, is incredibly expensive. So you definitely want individuals with deep pockets to cut those $50 million checks that a campaign or a PAC can utilize to their advantage.But I would agree with Alencia broadly speaking, those individuals who are giving those small dollar donations to Vice President Harris and former President Trump, they expect that their issues will take precedent over wealthier individuals. And I wouldn't be of the mindset that it should.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes. Let's talk --

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: Billionaire has Shermichael and I agree.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Billionaires have that ability. Yes. Billionaires. Billionaires.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: Billionaires, right.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So Jasmine, let me ask you because speaking of JD Vance --

utterances.speaker: JASMINE WRIGHT, POLITICS REPORTER, NOTUS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: -- Donald Trump, former President Trump did an interview with Fox where he was basically asked to defend some of the comments that JD Vance has said about this, you know, childless cat ladies disparaging Democrats who don't have kids therefore don't have any skin in the game, according to him. Here is Donald Trump trying to defend his running mate.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) DONALD TRUMP, (R) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: He's not against anything. But he loves family. It's very important to him. But I know so many people they never met the right person, male or female that just never met the right person. They are unbelievable. They're every bit as good as anybody else that has the most beautiful --

utterances.speaker: LAURA INGRAHAM, FOX NEWS ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: So what do you say to women out there watching who may not have --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I think they understand it.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: How do you think he did there defending his running?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WRIGHT
utterances.sentences: A place that he never ever wants to be.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And Jeff, CNN's KFile reviewed some of Vance's comments that he fundraised after those comments, the childless cat lady comments, in a series of 2020 and 2021 e-mails, he called Democratic leaders, quote, "childless sociopaths" who, quote, "don't have a direct stake in this country." This doesn't seem to be going away anytime soon.

utterances.speaker: JEFF MASON, WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT, REUTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't think he's fundraising on it now.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: I think that's (inaudible) anyway. Yes.

utterances.speaker: MASON
utterances.sentences: The other side is fundraising on it now. And that's, yes, I mean, it's interesting to me how much that is taken off, especially given the fact that there's a wealth of quotes, probably from JD Vance, but certainly from President Donald Trump that can be and will be used against that ticket in this race. But this one in particular has resonated so much because it affects people on both sides of the political line. There are single people out there who are Republican and Democrat who don't have children.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Both senators from South Carolina, for example.

utterances.speaker: MASON
utterances.sentences: Exhibit A. And that just shows how offensive it was to so many people. And it's to people who they really need.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So, Meghan McCain noted recently that her dad's campaign picks Sarah Palin as his vice president without even knowing at the time that Sarah Palin's teenage daughter was pregnant at the time. The Democratic vice presidential vetting process moving even faster than normal. Are you concerned at all about, you know -- I mean, it's tough to pick a running mate.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, look, we are less than 100 days out, we are in the middle of the sprint, this is no longer a marathon. And sure, there are probably going to be some things that we don't on Earth, and this is very quick vetting, but I'm not as concerned because of all of the candidates or the white men who are running very openly for this position. You know, a lot of people know them, at least in their states, and there's a lot of information out there already. And so, I am confident in our process. And I am hopeful, I'm saying that very cautiously, that we won't have the same surprise.But for us, it is about who they can speak to, the part of the electorate that maybe Kamala Harris cannot speak to as well. And so, we're focused there and who can do that the best.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Speaking of Kamala Harris, Democratic Senator Jon Tester of Montana, sees in a tough reelection battle in that state of Montana, still not ready to endorse the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee saying, quote, "You guys keep telling me that I have the toughest race in the country. That's what I'm focused on. I'm focused on Montana and a defense bill that we're getting out on Thursday." He's the lone holdout in the Senate.But there are some vulnerable Democrats in the House also refusing to say who they're going to vote for, refusing to say they support Kamala Harris. Does that work, do you think?

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: I mean, I don't think it really matters, Jake, in the grand scheme of things, and I think the Vice President is probably sophisticated enough to understand that Montana is a somewhat conservative state. I've gone pheasant hunting, they're just a different type of people --

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You are fancy. SINGLETON

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Did you get any pheasant?

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes. What were you using? What kind of gun?

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: We're not going to do that, Jake.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Thanks all for being here. Thanks all for --

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: No, Audie (ph) says it really like my guns stuff too much.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: In our law and justice lead, new questions today about how Chief Justice John Roberts is wielding his power on the U.S. Supreme Court over the years. Roberts has established a reputation as something of a consensus builder trying to bridge between the conservatives and the liberals. However, now that conservatives hold a six to three majority, Roberts might be turning into a different and weaker kind of power broker. CNN's Joan Biskupic is here with some exclusive behind the scenes reporting and how this played out in perhaps the biggest case of the court's latest term, the Trump presidential immunity case. You've learned that Roberts made actually no attempt to arrive at any sort of consensus.

utterances.speaker: JOAN BISKUPIC, CNN CHIEF SUPREME COURT ANALYST
utterances.sentences: It was a real surprise, Jake, because think of the public expectations, think of the expectations even among some of his colleagues inside, he's always tried to make efforts to bring the right and the left together, especially in major questions of presidential power. And after we heard oral arguments, you know, there seemed to be so many ways that the justices could split giving something to president, former president Trump certainly, you know, vindicating him to some degree, but also giving special counsel Jack Smith, a measure of success, too. But when they got around the conference table for that first, a straight six, three, all six of the Republican appointed conservatives voting for former president Donald Trump, the three Democrat appointed liberals against it. And the negotiations from their own out was were only conducted on the side of the conservatives.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Once the six conservatives banded together --

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: -- in this Trump presidential immunity case. Was there any point of contention among them? Are there -- to put it in a different way, among the six, are there factions within the six?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So has Roberts given up on the idea of being a consensus builder, because he knows it would be better to have a nine to zero decision instead of a six to three decision? Or is this just kind of like his attempt to like be relevant, because so few of the justices followed his lead on, you know, for instance, Dobbs?

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: Yes, two years ago, he stood alone between his five brethren on the right, who are more conservative, and the three liberals. Yes, there is a sense, Jake, of if you can't beat them, join them. You know, he can't control the opinion unless he's in the majority. And he's in -- he was in the majority more than any other justice this session. But this session was a highly conservative, aggressive session for him.It really did break the pattern. And the question is, what kind of turning point is this for him? Will he be a different kind of Chief going into his next term, which is his 20th term on the bench? Or will he at times kind of switch back?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: I said it in 2001, I'll say it again, the best Supreme Court reporter in all the land, Joan Biskupic, thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: In our law and justice lead, new questions about the sheriff's deputy who shot and killed a black woman inside her own home. Sonya Massey had called the police to report a possible prowler near her home in Springfield, Illinois. She was then shot and killed by a sheriff's deputy Sean Grayson. He has since been fired and charged with first degree murder. But now new details about his troubling past are coming to light. Josh Campbell's been following this for us.And Josh, Grayson has a long history of disciplinary issues.

utterances.speaker: JOSH CAMPBELL, CNN SECURITY CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: He does indeed. And you know, you ask most law enforcement leaders across the country, what's the one trait you look for in an officer, they will tell you almost to a person it's good judgment. That's why law enforcement is a profession where past performance can be indicative of future results. We're learning from this individual he had twice been cited for DUI before while serving as an officer. But in this new audio we were able to obtain, this was from a disciplinary hearing, where he's essentially called on the carpet by his supervisors for putting incorrect information into a police report.At one time during this meeting, an officer actually pulls up Google Maps and says, look, there is no way that what you say is true geographically, you could not have seen the details of this traffic stop in a way that you indicate here. We'll play some of this audio for you, you can hear they're really laying into him. The words, the tone itself is calm, the words are very harsh. Have a listen. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) CHIEF DEPUTY NATHAN MILLER, LOGAN COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE: Seven months on, how are you still employed by us? SHERIFF'S DEPUTY SEAN GRAYSON: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: MILLER
utterances.sentences: If we can't trust what you say and what you see, we can't have you in our uniform. Others will say you have no integrity, and you're lying to get to that traffic stop. And I have told you that I have zero tolerance for stretching the law. Because when you have officers that stretch the law, they will get caught, they will get prosecuted. I'm getting goosebumps.This is extremely concerning. Everybody likes you. I got to be able to trust you. Was this a purposefully done lie?

utterances.speaker: GRAYSON
utterances.sentences: No.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CAMPBELL
utterances.sentences: Now the supervisor in this disciplinary meeting tells that officer Grayson, that look, the U.S. Constitution dictates that you have to tell the truth. And indeed, the entire reputation of policing is dependent on people actually telling the truth. And you mentioned this concept that's called Giglio and this is in the legal profession, essentially, if a prosecutor knows that a witness such as a police officer testifying in a case has past disciplinary issues, they have to hand that over. That's why in law enforcement, people know that if you lie, if you do something wrong, you're essentially worthless as an officer because he can't testify. And so, really giving this lecture -- I will point out, Jake, finally, that there are questions for this department itself, because we know that Grayson had served in six police departments over the course of four years.At one point during this disciplinary meeting, they actually bring up the supervisor that says, look, I think it's your last department you engaged in the same kind of activity. So the question is, how was he hired here? And then how was he hired at the next department where he went where he was on duty that day that he actually shot and killed Sonia Massey. Jake, you and I have covered so many of these incidents where you see police officers bouncing around to different departments, that's the big question here. How do those in the police profession actually stop that? This appears to be a case in point, someone who just went department to department.

utterances.speaker: CAMPBELL
utterances.sentences: You bet.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: When redemption meets history, our next story combines them both and will make you smile. Stay with us.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: It is victory for Simone Biles and the USA women's gymnastics team. This afternoon they won the gold medal and the team final in Paris. Biles is now the most decorated American gymnast of all time with eight medals.There was a cheeky moment we want to share with you at the post when news conference when former American gymnast and Olympic gold medalist and past guest on The Lead Aly Raisman asked Biles about whether or not the team had an informal nickname it had given to itself for the games. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ALY RAISMAN, FORMER AMERICAN GYMNAST, OLYMPIC GOLD MEDALIST
utterances.sentences: What is your team name?SIMONE BILES, EIGHT-TIME OLYMPIC MEDALIST: What's your team name?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Don't say it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Don't say it.

utterances.speaker: BILES
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to say it.

utterances.speaker: RAISMAN
utterances.sentences: Abbreviate it. Just abbreviate it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes. Abbreviate.

utterances.speaker: BILES
utterances.sentences: F-A -- F around and find out. Oh, yes, yes, that was so easy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You said abbreviate it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, I did.(END VIDEO CLIP)
